displayed_text: Family Member: That class, is that here? Or is that a web cast? Doctor: No, it’s here. Family Member: It’s here. Patient: Any need for a driver - chemo days, things like that? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So, on chemo days, you have to have a driver. Ummm. You may not need him. But, I mean, my sense is that if you start getting sick and nauseated, and I have to give you a medicine that’s sedating - I don’t want you getting behind the wheel of a car and driving home. Patient: Oh sure Doctor: But, if you don’t have any nausea, we have done everything that we needed to do and you feel great, you’ve got company to talk about – Hey, that wasn’t so bad. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: But, yeah, uh, you’ve gotta have a partner on those days. Patient: That’s fine. Just wanted to Doctor: There is no need to stay. She could leave for a couple of hours and come back. (chuckles)

Patient: Yeah. The um… Doctor: So the strength was worse? Patient: Right. Doctor: That was worse. That would be the reason then to do… Patient: Right, right. Doctor: …you know to lean towards surgery. Because if it’s going to take the pressure off the nerve… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: …and sort of prevent further damage. Patient: Right. Doctor: At least first of all maybe give your nerves a chance to recover at least it prevents total further loss of - Patient: Right. Doctor: -strength and all that.

Patient: Tomorrow I’m going to this local one. I have a schedule with Dr. ___in January because the last neurologist that I saw, the one that put the catheter in, told me the catheter should not be taken out in less than four to six weeks. It should be replaced in every four to six weeks if necessary. Doctor: Sure. Patient: So when I talked to ___, he said okay, then come in January and then we’ll that procedure. So I don’t know if I should go there. I don’t even know what else he can do. I didn’t have chance to talk to him personally. I talked to nurse and she did not explain correctly. Looks like he can’t do anything for me except the nurse is taking catheter out and putting it in. So what other treatments he’s going to give me, I don’t know. Doctor: Dr. ____ or Patient: Dr. ____. Doctor: And the issue really is we’d like to get the catheter out and sort of when is your bladder strong enough to take it out, if we’ve shrunk the cancer with the hormone therapy – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - is there enough of a channel for you to pee on our own? Doctor: So all of that – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - is what urologists do. Patient: Right, I know. So anyway, I have it scheduled.

Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, so they randomize you to just standard treatment, then you wouldn’t get the- Patient: There’s seventy percent I will get the real thing? Doctor: Two out of three. Yes. Yeah. Patient: Hum. But, uh, for some reason I want to quit or couldn’t make anymore, I could just stop? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. If you’re not tolerating it or if there are issues, yeah. Patient: I don’t think I’d have any trouble tolerating. Doctor: Yeah. It doesn’t seem like, from everything I’m gathering about this medication, it seems like it’s been easy to tolerate. There may be some infusion reaction or, you know-. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Some occasional side effects, but we’ll be monitoring your blood labs, liver function, kidney function, all of that, every time before we give you that injection. Family Member: So- Doctor: So you’ll be monitored.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Then I would just proceed with the Xtandi and start it. Okay? (Sound Door closes) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The other piece of this that’s an unknown piece is, we have some sets that the people who got testosterone, even the ones that didn’t respond to it, seemed to have a better response to drugs like Xtandi or Zytiga afterwards. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And our, our idea is maybe that the cells have gotten used to being low testosterone and they’ve kind of adjusted. Then we put them in high testosterone, they adjust to that- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I ain’t gotta take no shots, no hip shots, or Doctor: You are due for your Lupron. So, Patient: Which one is that? Doctor: The hormone. The Lupron shot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So, let me see if you want. Do you want to do it today? Patient: I mean Doctor: You can go over and do it. Patient: What? Doctor: To the treatment area.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh. (pause) Patient: Right. Doctor: That it’s clear that this isn’t helping you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, we could say, “No, let’s move on.” I can give you the, uh, consent forms. But, if you already know, that I don’t want to do chemotherapy, I know I’m not going to come in here. The consent form does explain chemotherapy. So, that’s something that you’d be entertaining as a next step, whether it be here or locally. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That also tells you about chemo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The vitamin C part would only be done here. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, so, that would be, letting you go through that process to sort of say, “Okay. That’s the more traditional next step.” Um. The other one is a window phase one. Is that you have therapy, you’re not ready to go to chemotherapy, I’m willing to try something under our observations with blood tests and scans. That if the cancer would sort of wildly changing, we abort and do chemotherapy.

Family Member 1: Write that down. Doctor: It's more like she’s going to be tough for you. And the mask can only do so much. Family Member 1: In case she picks up a virus from her. Family Member 2: She goes to classes around other kids. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it? Doctor: It's just not ideal. You know, if I if you know, she's already got the snotty nose and all that. Family Member 1: Fam1 hold back. Doctor: You know kind of maybe just don't want to hang there. You know, they're not sick all the time. But sometimes you don't know like a fever comes after they’ve been crabby for the day, and you've been exposed. So just trying to minimize- Family Member 1: So let me repeat this. On the chemo- it’s safe for him to be around her. Doctor: Yeah, she’s not getting cancer. Family Member 2: He can kiss her.

Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have some data that says says, um, people tolerate the chemo better once, uh, they have a little bit more space between getting the hormones and the chemo together. So Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let your body’s level of testosterone drop. Then, get the chemo, uh - that may be safer on your bone marrow than doing it all at once. Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, we might need, if it’s something that frequent, we might need a port. Yeah, that’s a lot of beating up on you. You know, once every three weeks Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: you can get away with that and it’s like an hour but if you’re here twice a week it’s pretty painful. Patient: That’s possible that I don’t have to do that, right? Doctor: Well, you could always say no. You could say listen, I just want the chemo and I don’t want the vitamin C trial, just you know forget it and we would just do straight chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Of course, I always encourage you guys if it’s available to do the trial because you get a shot at new stuff, you know. I know it’s not a hundred percent shot but it’s better than, it’s not zero so. We’ll talk more Patient: Okay, Alright yeah lets. Doctor: in depth on that. That way you know the schedule, Patient: Right. Doctor: the potential side effects, you know, and you have to decide if it’s worth it for you but I appreciate both of you keeping an open mind which you have done so. Patient: Yes, I have, you know.

Patient: Xtandi? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And the Zofran, you take it as needed. Anything else that I need to add to this list, that we don’t have on this list? Patient: No. No. Doctor: Nothing for moving your bowels, slow your bowels down? Family Member: Oh you don’t do that Patient: No, I’m not taking a stool softener anymore. Family Member: Okay. Patient: When I was on the uh, radiation, I was having some problems, so stool softeners and laxative pill but I haven’t used that for the last three to four days so it’s still working, naturally. Doctor: Did you get radiated recently? Patient: Yeah, end of December - finished I think it was the third of January. Doctor: What did you radiate?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: And if that happens, what if all of a sudden he spikes a fever and it happens at night, uh - Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah, that’s right. No, one-eight hundred _____. That is like a twenty-four-hour line. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You can do it yourself, but then you’re flustered. It’s a little bit complicated, - Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s why I prefer; you know I tell people - Patient: Right, yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: to just you may want use that one-eight hundred number. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: It’s easier. It takes away the fact of you having to follow the instructions. Family Member: All right. Doctor: And that is on my card if you really want to use that.

Patient: Yeah. Thursday afternoon. Doctor: Afternoon, sorry. Got it. Family Member: So let’s – okay so that happens. Then what happens next? Doctor: So at that point if everything is looking good we will also be scheduling the biopsy and then the treatment date after that. Patient: And when do I start on the BET? Doctor: So the… Family Member: Not ‘til the biopsy. Doctor: …plan would be maybe two weeks or three weeks from today. Patient: And that would be after the biopsy? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Uh… Family Member: Any other tests that we need to know about? Blood work and bone biopsy?

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer. Patient: There’s no radiation, there’s no chemo that, uh no combination of chemotherapy that - Doctor: Right. Patient: - would be able to kind of target - see the - my my biggest concern with the scans was that because this kin to prostate cancer, this metast, metasta - however it’s supposed to… Family Member: Metastasized. Doctor: Metastasized. Patient: …has metastasized to a point where that it’s still chemically – t - it hasn’t landed anywhere in layman’s terms, my words.
